text.text:
‚úÖ Grammar for IELTS

üî±The Simple Past and Present Perfect Verb Tenses

üî∑Ô∏èWhen using the past tense, we see these past actions¬†as having no connection with the present. They¬†belong¬†to the past, so we use the¬†past tense¬†to express them.

I¬†ate¬†my breakfast with Tony and then we¬†saw¬†a movie.

The action above happened in the past. There is no connection with the present, so we use the¬†simple past.

üî∂Ô∏èIf, however, the action happened in the past but it has some kind of impact on the present, or if it continues into the present, we need to use the¬†present perfect.

I¬†haven‚Äôt eaten¬†breakfast yet, I‚Äôm starving.

The above is present perfect because it is a past action but it has¬†an obvious impact on the present, the speaker is now hungry.

I¬†have been waiting¬†here since 10 a.m.

The above is present perfect because the action started in the past but is continuing into the present, when the speaker is¬†stillwaiting.

text:
Here are 20 simple rules and tips to help you avoid mistakes in English grammar.

üè†

text_entities.text:
Here are 20 simple rules and tips to help you avoid mistakes in English grammar.

üè†

text:
A sentence starts with a capital letter and ends with a period/full stop, a question mark or an exclamation mark. see Punctuation

‚ñ∫ The fat cat sat on the mat.
‚ñ∫ Where do you live?
‚ñ∫ My dog is very clever!

text_entities.text:
A sentence starts with a capital letter and ends with a period/full stop, a question mark or an exclamation mark. see Punctuation

‚ñ∫ The fat cat sat on the mat.
‚ñ∫ Where do you live?
‚ñ∫ My dog is very clever!

messages.text:
üî± ùó•ùó®ùóüùóò 2 üî±

The order of a basic positive sentence is Subject-Verb-Object. (Negative and question sentences may have a different order.)

‚ñ∫ John loves Mary.
‚ñ∫ They were driving their car to Bangkok.

text_entities.text:
üî± ùó•ùó®ùóüùóò 2 üî±

The order of a basic positive sentence is Subject-Verb-Object. (Negative and question sentences may have a different order.)

messages.text:
üî± ùó•ùó®ùóüùóò 3 üî±

Every sentence must have a subject and a verb. An object is optional. Note that an imperative sentence may have a verb only, but the subject is understood. 

‚ñ∫ John teaches.
‚ñ∫ John teaches English.
‚ñ∫ Stop! (i.e. You stop!)

text_entities.text:
üî± ùó•ùó®ùóüùóò 3 üî±

messages.text:
üî± ùó•ùó®ùóüùóò 4 üî±

The subject and verb must agree in number, that is a singular subject needs a singular verb and a plural subject needs a plural verb.

‚ñ∫ John works in London.
‚ñ∫ That monk eats once a day.
‚ñ∫ John and Mary work in London.
‚ñ∫ Most people eat three meals a day.

text_entities.text:

messages.text:
üî± ùó•ùó®ùóüùóò 5 üî±

When two singular subjects are connected by or, use a singular verb. The same is true for either/or and neither/nor.

‚ñ∫ John or Mary is coming tonight.
‚ñ∫ Either coffee or tea is fine.
‚ñ∫ Neither John nor Mary was late

messages.text:
üî± ùó•ùó®ùóüùóò 6  üî±

Adjectives usually come before a noun (except when a verb separates the adjective from the noun).

‚ñ∫ I have a big dog.
‚ñ∫ She married a handsome Italian man.
‚ñ∫ (Her husband is rich.)

messages.text:
üî± ùó•ùó®ùóüùóò 7  üî±

When using two or more adjectives together, the usual order is opinion-adjective + fact-adjective + noun. (There are some additional rules for the order of fact adjectives.)

‚ñ∫ I saw a nice French table.
‚ñ∫ That was an interesting Shakespearian play.

messages.text:
üî± ùó•ùó®ùóüùóò 8 üî±


Treat collective nouns (e.g. committee, company, board of directors) as singular OR plural. In BrE a collective noun is usually treated as plural, needing a plural verb and pronoun. In AmE a collective noun is often treated as singular, needing a singular verb and pronoun.

‚ñ∫ The committee are having sandwiches for lunch. Then they will go to London. (typically BrE)

‚ñ∫ The BBC have changed their logo. (typically BrE)

‚ñ∫ My family likes going to the zoo. (typically AmE)

‚ñ∫ CNN has changed its logo. (typically AmE)

messages.text:
üî± ùó•ùó®ùóüùóò 9 üî±

The words its and it's are two different words with different meanings.

‚ñ∫ The dog has hurt its leg.
‚ñ∫ He says it's two o'clock.

‚ñ∫ You're looking good.

üî± ùó•ùó®ùóüùóò 10 üî±

The words your and you're are two different words with different meanings.

‚ñ∫ Here is your coffee.
‚ñ∫ You're looking good.

messages.author: Flex
messages.text:
üî± ùó•ùó®ùóüùóò 11 üî±

The words there, their and they're are three different words with different meanings.

‚ñ∫ There was nobody at the party.
‚ñ∫ I saw their new car.
‚ñ∫ Do you think they're happy?

text_entities.text:
üî± ùó•ùó®ùóüùóò 11 üî±

The words there, their and they're are three different words with different meanings.

‚ñ∫ There was nobody at the party.
‚ñ∫ I saw their new car.
‚ñ∫ Do you think they're happy?

messages.author: Flex
messages.text:
üî± ùó•ùó®ùóüùóò 12 üî±

The contraction he's can mean he is OR he has. Similarly, she's can mean she is OR she has, and it's can mean it is OR it has, and John's can mean John is OR John has.

‚ñ∫ He is working
‚ñ∫ He has finished.
‚ñ∫ She is here.
‚ñ∫ She has left.
‚ñ∫ John is married.
‚ñ∫ John has divorced his wife.

text_entities.text:

‚ñ∫ He is working

messages.text:
üî± ùó•ùó®ùóüùóò 13 üî±

The contraction he'd can mean he had OR he would. Similarly, they'd can mean they had OR they would.

‚ñ∫ He had eaten when I arrived.
‚ñ∫ He would eat more if possible.
‚ñ∫ They had already finished.
‚ñ∫ They would come if they could.

messages.author: Flex
messages.text:
üî± ùó•ùó®ùóüùóò 14 üî±

Spell a proper noun with an initial capital letter. A proper noun is a "name" of something, for example Josef, Mary, Russia, China, British Broadcasting Corporation, English.

‚ñ∫ We have written to Mary.
‚ñ∫ Is China in Asia?
‚ñ∫ Do you speak English?

üî± ùó•ùó®ùóüùóò 15 üî±

Spell proper adjectives with an initial capital letter. Proper adjectives are made from proper nouns, for example Germany ‚Üí German, Orwell ‚Üí Orwellian, Machiavelli ‚Üí Machiavellian.

‚ñ∫ London is an English town.
‚ñ∫ Who is the Canadian prime minister?

messages.text:
üî± ùó•ùó®ùóüùóò 16 üî±

Use the indefinite article a/an for countable nouns in general. Use the definite article the for specific countable nouns and all uncountable nouns.

‚ñ∫ I saw a bird and a balloon in the sky. The bird was blue and the balloon was yellow.
‚ñ∫ He always saves some of the money that he earns.

messages.text:
üî± ùó•ùó®ùóüùóò 17 üî±

Use the indefinite article a with words beginning with a consonant sound. Use the indefinite article an with words beginning with a vowel sound. see When to Say a or an

‚ñ∫ a cat, a game of golf, a human endeavour, a Frenchman, a university (you-ni-ver-si-ty)

‚ñ∫ an apple, an easy job, an interesting story, an old man, an umbrella, an honorable man (on-o-ra-ble)

messages.text:
üî± ùó•ùó®ùóüùóò 18 üî±

Use many or few with countable nouns. Use much/a lot or little for uncountable nouns. see Quantifiers

‚ñ∫ How many dollars do you have?
‚ñ∫ How much money do you have?
‚ñ∫ There are a few cars outside.
‚ñ∫ There is little traffic on the roads.

messages.text:
üî± ùó•ùó®ùóüùóò 19 üî±

To show possession (who is the owner of something) use an apostrophe + s for singular owners, and s + apostrophe for plural owners.

‚ñ∫ The boy's dog. (one boy)
‚ñ∫ The boys' dog. (two or more boys)

In general, use the active voice (Cats eat fish) in preference to the passive voice (Fish are eaten by cats).

‚ñ∫ We use active in preference to passive.

text.text: Learn English Tenses: Present Simple or Present Continuous?

text: ‚ÄúI work‚Äù or ‚ÄúI am working‚Äù? In this easy English lesson, you will learn the difference between the PRESENT SIMPLE TENSE (‚ÄúI work‚Äù) and the PRESENT CONTINUOUS (PROGRESSIVE) TENSE (‚ÄúI am working‚Äù). Many students get confused, because these two tenses do not exist in all languages. Here, we‚Äôll review when to use each tense, how to form it, and what common mistakes to avoid. We‚Äôll do practice exercises together, so you can understand the differences clearly.

= more than one time, occasionally

text: Should you use¬†WILL¬†or¬†GOING TO¬†to talk about the future? In this lesson, I‚Äôll explain the differences so you can understand easily when you should use ‚Äúwill‚Äù and when you should use ‚Äúgoing to‚Äù. You‚Äôll know which one to use for formal or informal situations and planned or unplanned activities. Together, we‚Äôll review when to use them, how to use them, and what common mistakes to avoid. We‚Äôll compare the two options and do practice exercises together, so you feel confident about your English grammar.

messages.text: Complete English Grammar Rules

messages.file: (File not included. Change data exporting settings to download.)

text.text:
Complete English Grammar Rules 
Examples, Exceptions, Exercises & Everything You need to Master proper Grammar.

text_entities.text:
Complete English Grammar Rules 
Examples, Exceptions, Exercises & Everything You need to Master proper Grammar.

text:
It's or Its?

It's: it is/it has
‚Ä¢It's big. (It is)
‚Ä¢It's a surprise. (It is)
‚Ä¢It's not a problem. (It is)
‚Ä¢It's begun snowing. (It has)
‚Ä¢It's taken a very long time. (It has)
‚Ä¢It's been quite windy all week. (It has)

Its: belonging to it/of it
‚Ä¢Its paws are big. (The dog's)
‚Ä¢Its legs are uneven. (The table's)
‚Ä¢Its kitchen is modern. (The house's)
‚Ä¢Its offspring are happy. (The animal's)
‚Ä¢Its camera is very good. (The phone's)
‚Ä¢Its parking garage is small. (The mall's)

English

text: 'I'm' is an abbreviation for the word 'I AM.' It is used in combination with other words to tell someone about yourself or to describe something you are doing.

"I'm so tired."
"I'm confused."
"I'm happy."
"I'm twenty three years old."
"I'm hungry."
"I'm nervous."
"I'm excited."
"I'm leaving work."
"I'm thirsty."
"I'm from Seattle."

text.text: You can also add descriptive words with 'I'm' such as:

text:
"I'm extremely tired."
"I'm very happy."
"I'm terribly hungry."
"I am super excited."
"I'm very nervous."

text: It‚Äôs time to learn the PRESENT PERFECT. What does it mean to say ‚ÄúI have worked‚Äù or ‚ÄúI have understood‚Äù? Many students are confused by the PRESENT PERFECT TENSE, because it combines the past and the present. Yet this advanced verb tense can lead to success in a job interview or on your IELTS! In this complete English class, I‚Äôll show you how to use this tense, when to use it, and what mistakes to avoid. You will move forward step-by-step, to master this tense by learning structure, usage, pronunciation, spelling, contractions, questions, short answers, past participles, regular verbs, and irregular verbs. Then, continue your progress through my complete English Tenses series by watching the next lesson, which compares the present perfect and past simple tenses.

text.text:
‚≠êÔ∏èI'm in/at/on

Describes an action you are doing.

text: Most commonly, you would use the word 'in' when entering a physical location such as a room or a building.

"I'm in the shower."
"I'm in the lobby."
"I'm in a car."
"I'm in a house."
"I'm in a school."

Using the word 'at' helps tell someone where you currently are. The difference between 'at' and 'in' is that the physical location is general.

Here are some examples:

"I'm at the grocery."
"I'm at the mall."
"I'm at the doctor's office."
"I'm at the park."
"I'm at the airport."

However, in some cases you can use 'at' and 'in' interchangeably.

"I'm at the mall."
"I'm in the mall."
"I'm at the park."
"I'm in the park."
"I'm at the grocery."
"I'm in the grocery."

Using the word 'on' is referring to a non physical location such as your time being utilized by something else.

Here are some examples:

"I'm on the phone."
"I'm on my computer."
"I'm on a bus."

text.text: >>‚ú™- click the link to learn more:

text: What‚Äôs the difference between ‚ÄúI worked‚Äù and ‚ÄúI have worked‚Äù? In this easy English grammar class, we‚Äôll review the PAST SIMPLE TENSE and the PRESENT PERFECT TENSE, so you know exactly when to use each. I‚Äôll explain when to use each tense, how to form it, and what common mistakes to avoid. We‚Äôll do practice exercises together, so you can use the right tense at the right time. This video is part of the engVid series on all the English verb tenses, from beginner to advanced levels. So join me and master these tenses to improve your general, business, or academic English, including for English exams like the IELTS and TOEFL. The next lesson in this series is on the PRESENT PERFECT CONTINUOUS tense.

text.text:
‚≠êÔ∏èI'm + (verb)

'I'm' is a contraction of the words 'I am.' By adding a verb to 'I'm' this lets you express an action or occurrence about yourself.

Here are some examples:

"I'm eating lunch."
"I'm brushing my teeth."
"I'm scared."
"I'm driving to work."
"I'm crying."
"I'm typing an email."
"I'm cooking dinner."
"I'm combing my hair."
"I'm hanging a picture."
"I am texting."
"I am dancing."
"I am interested in the job."
"I am exercising."
"I am sad."
"I am learning."

text.text:
I'm getting

When combining the words 'I am' and 'getting' you are telling someone 'you' are gaining possession, being affected by or have plans to seek out and obtain a particular thing.

Here are some examples:

"I'm getting better."
"I'm getting ready for bed."
"I'm getting a tooth ache."
"I'm getting a cold."
"I'm getting married."
"I'm getting tired."
"I'm getting good at reading."
"I'm getting a new car."
"I'm getting a job."
"I'm getting a puppy."

text.text:
Gotta, Gonna, Wanna
Question

Does "gotta" mean "going to"?

text:
Answer

Gotta, gonna, and wanna are common informal words used in writing to represent rapid speech. Gotta means "got to," gonna means "going to," and wanna means "want to."

Here are some additional pronunciation spellings you may see or hear:

dunno = don't know
gotcha = got you
lemme = let me
gimme = give me

text.text: Here are examples of each in a sentence:

text:
I've gotta get home before dark.
He's gonna be a chef when he grows up.
I wanna eat lunch before we leave to run errands.
"Where's Sam?" "I dunno."
Don't worry about paying for your half of the pizza--I gotcha =I'll pay for your half too.
Hey, lemme see that book!
Just gimme a minute--I'll come pick you up as soon as I'm done at work.
 
I hope this helps.

text: Meaning: This type of activity doesn't suit me.  I am not good at this.

That stinks! Who cut the cheese?

Cut me some slack. It's my first time.
Cut to the chase and tell me what happened.

text.text: Learn English Tenses: PRESENT PERFECT CONTINUOUS

text: What does it mean when someone says: ‚ÄúI have been working‚Äù? This advanced tense is called the PRESENT PERFECT CONTINUOUS or PRESENT PERFECT PROGRESSIVE. It shows that an action started in the past and continues into the present. In this English grammar class, I‚Äôll teach you how to use this verb tense, when to use it, and what mistakes to avoid. We‚Äôll focus on structure, usage, spelling, pronunciation, contractions, questions, short answers, stative verbs, and irregular verbs. We‚Äôll move forward step-by-step and do practice exercises together, so you understand clearly. This class is part of my engVid series on English verb tenses.

text.text: IELTS Grammar: Tips for improving your gramatical range

text:
So here are 5¬†great ways to improve your band score for¬†IELTS grammar.

üìå 1. Use subordinating conjunctions

üìçJoin clauses with because, so that, although, while, whereas

üìå 2. Use relative clauses

Add information by using relative clauses

‚ùå So don't write "The cat was sitting on the wall. It was being stroked by a girl." Write:

‚úÖ The cat, which was sitting on the wall, was being stroked by a¬†girl.

üìå 3. Use 'there' + 'to be'

This is a simple, yet very¬†underused grammatical structure. It is a very¬†powerful structure because it forces you to change the grammar of the rest¬†of the sentence. It makes you turn verbs into noun phrases and adjective phrases, and it makes you change the word order (the syntax) of your sentence. 
üìùIn other words, "there + to be"¬†makes you widen your grammatical range.

‚ùå So instead of writing: "A cat was sitting on the wall", you can write:

‚úÖ There was a cat sitting on the wall.

It looks similar, but "sitting on the wall" is now an adjective phrase, not a verb.

‚ùå Instead of writing: "From 1995 to 2005, sales fluctuated slightly", you can write:

‚úÖ There was a slight fluctuation in sales from 1995 to 2005.

üìå 4. Start the sentence with a subordinating conjunction

‚ùå Instead of "the cat was sitting on the wall because she was tired" write:

‚úÖ Because she was tired, the cat was sitting on the wall.

üìå 5. Start the sentence with a prepositional phrase

üìù Common prepositional phrases start with since, at, among, about, throughout, with regards to, in time. For example:
   
‚úÖ Since the beginning of the afternoon, the cat had been sitting on the wall.

text_entities.text: IELTS Grammar: Tips for improving your gramatical range

So here are 5¬†great ways to improve your band score for¬†IELTS grammar.

üìå 1. Use subordinating conjunctions

üìçJoin clauses with because, so that, although, while, whereas

üìå 2. Use relative clauses

Add information by using relative clauses

‚ùå So don't write "The cat was sitting on the wall. It was being stroked by a girl." Write:

‚úÖ The cat, which was sitting on the wall, was being stroked by a¬†girl.

üìå 3. Use 'there' + 'to be'

This is a simple, yet very¬†underused grammatical structure. It is a very¬†powerful structure because it forces you to change the grammar of the rest¬†of the sentence. It makes you turn verbs into noun phrases and adjective phrases, and it makes you change the word order (the syntax) of your sentence. 
üìùIn other words, "there + to be"¬†makes you widen your grammatical range.

‚ùå So instead of writing: "A cat was sitting on the wall", you can write:

‚úÖ There was a cat sitting on the wall.

It looks similar, but "sitting on the wall" is now an adjective phrase, not a verb.

‚ùå Instead of writing: "From 1995 to 2005, sales fluctuated slightly", you can write:

‚úÖ There was a slight fluctuation in sales from 1995 to 2005.

üìå 4. Start the sentence with a subordinating conjunction

‚ùå Instead of "the cat was sitting on the wall because she was tired" write:

‚úÖ Because she was tired, the cat was sitting on the wall.

üìå 5. Start the sentence with a prepositional phrase

üìù Common prepositional phrases start with since, at, among, about, throughout, with regards to, in time. For example:
   
‚úÖ Since the beginning of the afternoon, the cat had been sitting on the wall.

text:
Now, in this first part, I‚Äôd like to ask you some more questions about yourself, OK?  Let‚Äôs talk about your home town or village. What kind of place is it? 

üîπ

It‚Äôs quite a small village, about 20km from Zurich. And it‚Äôs very quiet. And we have only little ... two little shops because most of the people work in Zurich or are orientated to the city. 
 
üî∏
What‚Äôs the most interesting part of this place ... village?
On the top of a hill we have a little castle which is very old and quite well known in Switzerland.
What kind of jobs do people in the village do?
We have some farmers in the village as well as people who work in Zurich as bankers or journalists or there are also teachers and some doctors, some medicines.
Would you say it‚Äôs a good place to live?
Yes. Although it is very quiet, it is ‚Ä¶ people are friendly and I would say it is a good place to live there, yes.
Let‚Äôs move on to talk about accommodation. Tell me about the kind of accommodation you live in ...

text:
Phrasal verbs in academic writing is different from speaking. It is highly formal and phrasal verbs are less formal for an academic discourse. So you can use phrasal verbs in speaking not in writing a research or an academic essay. They are used in emails between friends and informal situations only.
.

text.text: We use each with 2 or more things.

text:
- She has a bracelet on each arm.‚úÖ
- She has a bracelet on every arm.‚ùå

text.text: We use every with 3 or more things. So when talking about 3 or more things, they are basically the same.

text:
- Each voter received a sticker.‚úÖ
- Every voter received a sticker.‚úÖ

Although they are basically the same, when talking about 3 or more things, "each" focuses more on the INDIVIDUAL things (each one is separate), whereas "every" focuses more on the GROUP (they are all together). However, this is a very small difference that rarely affects the meaning of the sentence.

text.text: And finally, we can use "each of" but not "every of".

text:
- Each of them was invited.‚úÖ
- Every of them was invited.‚ùå

text.text: However, we can say "every one of".

text:
- Every one of them was invited.‚úÖ

And we sometimes use them together like this. ‚¨áÔ∏è

- Each and every one of them received a gift.‚úÖ

text.text:
‚õ≥Ô∏è I'm gonna + (verb)

The word 'gonna' is incorrect grammatically. The equivalent in proper grammar would be 'going to.' When using the word 'gonna' you are telling someone what you are planning to do at that moment or in the near future.

Here are some examples:

"I'm gonna have some coffee."
"I'm gonna go to work."
"I'm gonna eat some cake."
"I'm gonna send out my resume."
"I'm gonna run a marathon."
"I'm gonna ask her out for dinner."
"I'm gonna stop smoking."
"I'm gonna help my friends."
"I'm gonna take swim lessons."
"I'm gonna read a book."

text.text:
Today's story

How good we are!

text:
üòá

A little boy went into a drug store reached for a soda carton and pulled it over to the telephone. He climbed onto the carton so that he could reach the buttons on the phone and proceeded to punch in seven digits‚Ä¶
The store-owner observed and listened to the conversation.
The boy asked ‚Äúlady can you give me the job of cutting your lawn?‚Äù The woman replied" I already have someone to cut my lawn‚Äù. 
Lady, I will cut your lawn for half the price of the person who cuts your lawn now. Replied the boy. The woman responded that she was very satisfied with the person who was presently cutting her lawn. the little boy found more perseverance and offered" lady I'll even sweep your curb and your side walk so on Sunday you will have the prettiest lawn in all of palm beach Florida. Again the woman answered in the negative. With a smile on his face the little boy replaced the receiver. The store-owner who was listening to all walked over to the boy and said son I like your attitude I like that positive spirit and would like to offer you a job, the little boy replied no thanks, I was just checking my performance with the job, I already have. I am the one who is working for that lady I was talking to.

text.text:
‚õ≥Ô∏èI'm trying + (verb)

'I am trying' informs someone that you are attempting to accomplish something using bodily, mental, or spiritual strength. By adding a verb to 'I'm trying' you are pointing out exactly what it is you are attempting to do.

Here are some examples:

"I'm trying to get a job."
"I'm trying to call my family."
"I'm trying to enjoy my dinner."
"I'm trying to educate myself."
"I'm trying to explain myself."
"I'm trying new food."
"I'm trying to eat healthy."
"I'm trying to understand."

You may also hear the word 'trying' used to express a way someone is feeling. In this manner, it expresses strain or distress.

Here are some examples:

"Learning new things can be trying on you."
"That marathon was very trying on me."

text.text:
QUIT TIPS TO IMPROVE YOUR SPOKEN ENGLISH

1: Think in English

text:
The mind is truly a strong tool. It should be used as much as possible. Make it your habit of talking to yourself in English. Think in your mind before what you are going to say. Describe your thoughts about different things in English.

2:

text.text: Do not translate from your native language to English

text:
If you are unaware of the correct sentence or phrase in English, do not try to translate that in your native tongue. If you do this it will not take you towards effective learning. Don't make fun of yourself. Therefor, try to find out the correct usage which you may get by reading or asking someone.

3:

A good leaner will always try to take advantage of every single opportunity to speak things in English. At first, it may be a bit awkward to speak unnecessarily but considering that your first ever experience try to avail of that opportunity. Things will be automatically get better for you afterwards.


4:

text.text:
Learn sentences or phrases‚Äì
 don‚Äôt concentrate on single words.

text:
When you get some opportunity to learn few good words don't consider those words sufficient for your speaking rather you must try to learn other things like different sentences and phrases that are used in daily life. Try to use those words in different sentences. It will help you improve your vocabulary.

5:

Listen, listen, listen. Whether you have to use the radio or the television or a movie. Or a colleague or teacher who can speak a good English. listening continually can help you improve your pronunciation and accent. Your reading habit alone can't help you improve your speaking skills.

text.text: How can I improve my IELTS vocabulary?
Follow these tips to Improve IELTS Vocabulary:

text:
1. Make good time table of your study, and learn at 10 new important IELTS words everyday.

2. Your first focus is on making your own dictionary, must put new words into your own dictionary, and revise them.

3. Must practice the news words in your friends circle.

4. Try to write something using new words that you learn everyday.

5. Have a great focus on IELTS speaking section.

text: Do you ever use the PAST PERFECT TENSE (‚ÄúI had worked‚Äù)? Do you know this advanced tense can help you talk about the past in a special way? In this English grammar class, I‚Äôll teach you when to use this tense, how to use it, and what mistakes to avoid. You will learn: structure, usage, pronunciation, spelling, contractions, questions, short answers, past participles, and irregular verbs. We‚Äôll go forward systematically and practice together, so you understand fully. This class is part of the engVid program on ALL the English verb tenses, designed to take your English to a higher level for career growth or academic success on English exams like the IELTS or TOEFL. The next class in this series compares the past simple and past perfect tenses.

text.text:
Guidelines for writing

TYPES OF COMPOSITION

text: When you write a composition you need to understand the type of writing required. Your piece of writing can be in the form of a letter, an article for a magazine/newspaper or a report.

are written to a person (e.g. your pen friend, a newspaper editor, etc.) or a group of people (e.g. the students ' society, the local football club, etc.) for a specific reason (e.g. to give advice, to make a complaint, etc.). They include:
to people you know well, written in a personal chatty style. Below is an example of an informal letter:

text.text: Is it easy to get 7.5 in IELTS?

text: No, it is easy to score 7.5 bands in IELTS, you have to study hard and gird up your lions to do so. There are not so many ways to achieve this. You have to study hard, you have to be strong in every field, you should have excellent reading, listening, writing, and speaking skills to score 7.5 bands in IELTS.

text.text: How to study for IELTS at home

text:
You can study for IELTS at home, just follow these steps make them your daily routine:

1. Try to learn 10 new vocabulary words daily.

2. Find a speaking partner and practice daily. (

text.text: Use our Telegram group to find one

text:
). 

3. Have Some good vocabulary books for IELTS preparation.

4. For Making your motivation, read some success stories.

5. Do a bit of research on IELTS.

6. Write your new Words in a book. (Save your Vocabulary Collection)
7. Revise your vocabulary every day.

8. Practice, practice, and practice.

text.text: Here are 10 Easy Ways to Practice Speaking English

1. Sing English songs. 
2. Speak to your mirror every morning about what you are going to do and how you feel. 
3. Speak to your mirror in the evening about what you did and how you felt. 
4. Speak to yourself all day every day about what you are doing, what you need to do, how you feel, etc. 
5. Speak to your children/pets/plants.
6. Start a club with your friends where you only speak English. 
7. Repeat after me when you watch my videos. 
8. Repeat after the people on TV when you watch TV.
9. Make flashcards with full sentences and practice reading them out loud (speak the words) every day.
10. Read out loud (speak the words) when you are reading. Read the same thing again and again so that you are more confident each time you say it.

text:
Also, it doesn't matter whether or not your speaking partners are native English speakers.

You practice speaking to improve YOUR ABILITY to produce language and become more confident. The important thing is that YOU SPEAK, not who the other person is.

text_entities.text: Here are 10 Easy Ways to Practice Speaking English

1. Sing English songs. 
2. Speak to your mirror every morning about what you are going to do and how you feel. 
3. Speak to your mirror in the evening about what you did and how you felt. 
4. Speak to yourself all day every day about what you are doing, what you need to do, how you feel, etc. 
5. Speak to your children/pets/plants.
6. Start a club with your friends where you only speak English. 
7. Repeat after me when you watch my videos. 
8. Repeat after the people on TV when you watch TV.
9. Make flashcards with full sentences and practice reading them out loud (speak the words) every day.
10. Read out loud (speak the words) when you are reading. Read the same thing again and again so that you are more confident each time you say it.

Also, it doesn't matter whether or not your speaking partners are native English speakers.

You practice speaking to improve YOUR ABILITY to produce language and become more confident. The important thing is that YOU SPEAK, not who the other person is.

text:
My English is not well. ‚ùå
My English is not good. ‚úÖ
I don't speak English well. ‚úÖ

Adjectives describe nouns.
English is a noun.
Good is an adjective.
My English is not good.‚úÖ

Adverbs describe verbs (&adjectices&adverbs)
Speak is a verb.
Well is an adverb.
I don't speak English well.‚úÖ

*WELL can also be an adjective.
However, as an adjective, it means NOT SICK.

I am well. = I am not sick.
I am not well. = I am sick.

text:
Would you like some drink? ‚ùå
Would you like a drink? ‚úÖ
Would you like something to drink? ‚úÖ

"Drink" can be both a noun and a verb.

The problem with "some drink"  is that when "drink" is a noun, it is a countable noun, so it should have an S (some drinks).

And you can say "some drinks" but only if you are talking to more than one person, because "some drinks" means more than one drink.

text:
Checking in at the Airport‚úàÔ∏èüß≥üåê

üë©üèº Hello. Where are you flying to today?
üëµüèæ Washington DC.
üë©üèº Okay. May I have your passport, please?
üëµüèæ Here you go. (gives passport)
üë©üèº Thank you very much. Just one moment.
üëµüèæ (waits) 
üë©üèº And will you be checking any bags today?
üëµüèæ Yes, I have one bag to check. 
üë©üèº Okay, please place your bag on the scale.
üëµüèæ (places bag on scale)
üë©üèº Here is your passport and your boarding pass. (gives passport and boarding pass) 
üëµüèæ Thank you. 
üë©üèº Your flight is scheduled to take off on time at 10:45am, and your gate number is B7.
üëµüèæ Thank you very much.
üë©üèº You're welcome. Enjoy your time in DC.

"Here you are," and "Here you go," are just things that we say when we give something to someone.

"And will you be checking any bags today?" We often use future continuous to sound more polite when we are asking someone about their plans.

To "check a bag" means to put it under the plane. After you have checked it, it is called a "checked bag".

A small suitcase that you bring on the plane and put in the compartment above your head is called a "carry-on bag".

A smaller item such as a small backpack or purse is called a "personal item".

Washington DC is the capital of the United States. "DC" stands for (means) District of Columbia.

text:
üîä Global View - Carbon Footprint  
 
üÖ∞Ô∏è So what‚Äôs your guys‚Äô take on all this global warming hysteria in the media?

üÖ±Ô∏è It‚Äôs pretty serious, man. There have been tons of scientific studies and the scientific community says that the earth is heating up. We need to make some drastic changes to our lifestyle if we want to preserve our planet.

üÖ∞Ô∏è I don‚Äôt know. It sounds like a bunch of mumbo jumbo if you ask me. ‚ÄùSave the earth!‚Äù The earth will save itself. It‚Äôs survived worst disasters in the past. I mean, honestly, we live in the boonies. There‚Äôs no way anyone here is ever going to walk or bike to work, especially in the winter. And we have no bus system. My house is forty years old and it would take a lot of money to get it refitted to be ‚Äùgreen‚Äù and ‚Äùenergy-efficient‚Äù.

üÖæÔ∏è Well I don‚Äôt really know if I believe in global warming either, or whether or not it was our doing or a natural change the earth is going through, but you have to admit that we‚Äôre living pretty irresponsibly here in the west.

üÖ∞Ô∏è I guess...

üÖæÔ∏è I think the issue at hand is sustainability. We‚Äôve only got this one earth we can live on, and our resources are quickly disappearing because of our own carelessness and our inability to think of anyone but ourselves and anything but the present.

üÖ±Ô∏è So, like I was saying, we need to change the way we live. We need to reduce our carbon footprint.

üÖæÔ∏è But it doesn‚Äôt have to be that drastic. Hybrid vehicles and solar panels are too expensive to be feasible right now. And we don‚Äôt have to be hippies living off the land and buying everything organic either, though it helps.

üÖ±Ô∏è I car pool to work everyday with some buddies of mine. I have a rain barrel outside my house I use to water my plants and my lawn in the summer, and I make sure I always bring reusable bags with me when I get my groceries. And we just started using bio-degradable plastic made from corn oil for take-out orders at my family‚Äôs restaurant. Remember the three R‚Äôs? Reduce. Reuse. Recycle.

üÖæÔ∏è Exactly, it‚Äôs just small simple changes, like buying energy-saving light bulbs, starting a compost bin, recycling bottles and papers, using reusable water bottles, stop using disposable cups and cutlery.

üÖ∞Ô∏è Like the ones we‚Äôre drinking out of?

üÖ±Ô∏è Yeah.

üîé

text:
üë©üèΩ‚Äç‚öïÔ∏èWhat brings you here today?
ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èI'm not feeling well.
üë©üèΩ‚Äç‚öïÔ∏èWhat symptoms do you have?
ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èI have a headache, and I'm always tired. 
üë©üèΩ‚Äç‚öïÔ∏èHow long have you had these symptoms?
ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èSince I got married.
üë©üèΩ‚Äç‚öïÔ∏èDoes your husband help with housework?
ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èNo. He expects me to do everything.
üë©üèΩ‚Äç‚öïÔ∏èI'm going to write you a prescription.
ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èThank you. What is it for?
üë©üèΩ‚Äç‚öïÔ∏èA new husband.

What brings you here? = Why are you here?

When the doctor asks you about your

, they want to know what the problem is/how you feel.

*In the US, the doctor will not usually give you medicine. They will give you something called a PRESCRIPTION. A prescription is something written by a doctor that allows you to get a specific medicine from a pharmacy.

poll.question:
I've been so busy ________ I started my new job.

#GrammarQuiz

text:
üë© Good morning. Time to get up and get ready for school.
üëß But I don't want to go to school.
üë© You have to go to school, sweetie.
üëß Okay. Well, what's for breakfast?
üë© I'm making rice and eggs.
üëß I don't want rice and eggs.
üë© Then you can get a job and buy your own food.
üëß Rice and eggs sounds yummy. Thank you.
üë© Get up, take a shower, and brush your teeth. Breakfast will be ready in ten minutes.

*IT'S TIME TO... is often shortened to just TIME TO...  Time to go!  Time to eat!  Time to study!

*FOR is used to talk about meals.
What's for breakfast?
Where do you want to go for lunch?
I had chicken for dinner last night.

*Then you can get a job and buy your own food.
THEN is often used to mean "If that is the situation..."
üë® I don't want to be here.
üëµ Then you should leave.

text:
-an adverb
-can be used with all tenses
-means "perhaps"

-a verb phrase 
-used for the present and future only
-contains the verb BE
-focuses on someone/something BEING something

EXAMPLES:

Maybe I will go shopping. 
Maybe it will be fun. 
Maybe he is busy. 
Maybe she didn't know. 
Maybe the traffic was bad.

He may be a doctor.
We may be late.
She may be sleeping. 
It may be crowded.
There may be a problem.

text:
American Accent Training (Ebook + CD). American Accent Trainingg

American Accent Training is a book that teaches English pronunciation. This book is often used by lecturers and teachers in helping students to pronounce correctly. By using this books, students can improve their pronunciation of words, learn how to stress on the important part and connect the sounds.

In the books, the author explains about accents and the differences in British and American accent as well as provides information about basic sounds, consonants, vowels, double and single vowels, etc. The words are used as the example for you to practice pronouncing. Moreover, the book are divided into different unit with clear comparison of similar sounds to help you differentiate them and pratice.

text.text:
‚õ≥Ô∏èI have + (noun)

By using the words 'I have' you are informing someone of something you have possession of or have acquired.

Here are some examples:

"I have a cat."
"I have a nice car."
"I have a house."
"I have a computer."
"I have a headache."

You may hear the words 'cannot' and 'won't' used with 'I have.' By adding these you can express what you will not put up with or allow.

Here are some examples:

"I cannot have that behavior in my house."
"I cannot have you over tonight."
"I won't have anything to do with that."
"I won't have it any other way

text: This is the first first of ten, where I will teach you some of the most important English words that are advanced speakers

but often don't.

Feel more confident speaking with educated native speakers by using these words as a part of your vocabulary.

text_entities.text: Part 1 - 10 Advanced English Words for Fluent English.

but often don't.

text.text: Part 2 - 10 More Advanced English Words for Fluent English

text: Learn ten more advanced words to use when you speak English. Avoid using simple words (adjectives) with the word "very". This video will teach you how to express yourself better by expanding your vocabulary. Make sure that you watch until the end in order to practice linking (connecting words together) when you use these words in sentences. Keep practicing!

text.text: Has your mind ever gone blank when speaking a different language?

text: Here's the strategy to use if your mind goes blank whilst you are practicing for IELTS Speaking exam.

text.text:
Take a breath
2) Give yourself a moment to focus, and get your ideas back on track.
3) Use time fillers as a way to avoid silence like "let me think" "what I was saying".
4) If you get completely stuck go back to the question and talk about a personal experience relating back to the topic.

text.text: This essay will discuss the advantages and disadvantages of tourism

text:
. 

In the IELTS descriptors, repetition is mentioned under both Coherence and Cohesion and Lexical Resource. For Coherence and Cohesion it notes that band 5 essays ‚Äúmay be repetitive because of lack of referencing and substitution‚Äù. For Lexical Resource, it says that a band 4 essay might feature "basic vocabulary which may be used repeatedly." in other words, if your essay is filled with same words over and over, you might be stuck around band 4 or 5.

So today let's look at some alternatives phrases to "advantages and disadvantages".

IELTS Speaking tips 

In this speaking part, your vocabulary is tested - how wide your vocabulary range is. So, make sure to learn some alternatives ir synonyms of common English words.

For example the word "and" can be overused, so why don't you use some alternatives like

‚úÖAlso
‚úÖWhat's more
‚úÖToo
‚úÖAs well as

text: Usually, you should use in when you're taking about a small vehicle or a personal vehicle. Use on when you're taking about a large vehicle or a public vehicle. An exception to this is when you are talking about a bicycle or motorcycle, For small vehicles like those use on.

text_entities.text: Usually, you should use in when you're taking about a small vehicle or a personal vehicle. Use on when you're taking about a large vehicle or a public vehicle. An exception to this is when you are talking about a bicycle or motorcycle, For small vehicles like those use on.

üí°IELTS Speaking Tip

In the speaking part, your vocabulary is tested ‚Äî how wide your vocabulary range is. So, make sure to learn some alternatives or synonyms of common English words. 

For example the word ‚Äúand‚Äù can be overused, so why don‚Äôt you use some alternatives like
‚úÖ Besides
‚úÖ Also
‚úÖ What‚Äôs more
‚úÖ Too
‚úÖAs well

text:
Parts of the Day ü§é

Morning: 5 AM - 12 PM üèû
Afternoon: 12 PM - 6 PM üèñ
Evening: 6 PM - 9 PM üèô
Night: 9 PM - 4 AM üåÉ
Wee hours: 12 AM - 4 AM üåÜ

Noon/Midday - 12 PM üåï üïõ
Midnight - 12 AM üåô üïõ

Twilight comes right before sunrise, and right after sunset. üåÜ

And keep in mind, we say:
¬∑ IN THE morning / afternoon / evening
But
¬∑ AT noon / midnight / night / dusk / dawn / sunrise / sunset / twilight / wee hours

P.S. Sunset & Sunrise hours obviously change every single day depending on the season. üåÖ

messages.author: ÔΩ±ƒ¶Ã∂‚Ç≥ùôº…Üüá´üá∑

text.text:
üî∞Here are a bunch of phrasal verbs that you should knowüî∞

1. Opt for ‚ûñchoose
2. Patch ‚ûñreturn
3. Plump up ‚ûñfix / make things better
4. Polish off ‚ûñfinish / consume
5. Decide upon ‚ûñchoose / select
6. Die down ‚ûñdecrease
7. Get along ‚ûñleave
8. Hook up ‚ûñmeet (someone)
9. Jack up ‚ûñincrease sharply
10. Kick about ‚ûñdismiss
11. Talk about ‚ûñdismiss
12. Kick out ‚ûñexpel
13. Lay on ‚ûñorganise / support
14. Link up ‚ûñconnect / join
15. Make after ‚ûñchase
16. Make away with ‚ûñsteal
17. Big up ‚ûñexaggerate the importance
18. Book in ‚ûñcheck in at the a hotel
19. Blow up ‚ûñexplode
20. Call up ‚ûñtelephone
21. Cap off ‚ûñfinish / complete
22. Care for ‚ûñlike
23. Carry on ‚ûñcontinue
24. Carry off ‚ûñwin / succeed
25. Add on ‚ûñinclude

text: üëç Like | comment üí¨ | save | Share Turn on post notifications üîî

text.text:
Guidelines for writing

TYPES OF COMPOSITION

text: When you write a composition you need to understand the type of writing required. Your piece of writing can be in the form of a letter, an article for a magazine/newspaper or a report.

are written to a person (e.g. your pen friend, a newspaper editor, etc.) or a group of people (e.g. the students ' society, the local football club, etc.) for a specific reason (e.g. to give advice, to make a complaint, etc.). They include:
to people you know well, written in a personal chatty style. Below is an example of an informal letter:
to managers/officials etc., written in a polite formal style. Below is an example of a formal letter:
to people you do not know well or people you know but you want to sound polite and respectful e.g. a teacher of yours, your pen friend's parents, etc., written in a polite and respectful style.
are found in magazines and newspapers. The following can be found in the form of an article:
of people, places, buildings, objects, festivals, ceremonies etc.

about real or imaginary events which happened in the past. They can be written in the first person (first-person narratives) when the writer is the main character of the story or in the third person (third-person narratives) when the writer is describing
about current/recent events (e.g. fires, accidents, etc.) written in impersonal style. News reports present facts objectively and unemotionally.

discussing a film, TV program, book, restaurant, etc. and recommending
it or not to the reader.
about arguments concerning particular subjects. They include:
which present the pros and cons on a specific topic
which present the writer's personal opinion on a specific topic

to Problems which discuss a problem and its causes, making suggestions and mentioning the expected results and consequences

Letters to the Editor which present the writer's personal opinion on a specific topic or the writer's suggestions on a specific problem.

are formal pieces of writing and have a specific format and features. They include:

-Assessment reports discussing the suitability of a person, place, plan, etc. for a particular  purpose, job, etc.
-Proposals reports discussing suggestions or decisions about future actions.

messages.author: ÍßÅüòéùìíùì°700üòéÍßÇ

text.text: Here are 10 Easy Ways to Practice Speaking English

1. Sing English songs. 
2. Speak to your mirror every morning about what you are going to do and how you feel. 
3. Speak to your mirror in the evening about what you did and how you felt. 
4. Speak to yourself all day every day about what you are doing, what you need to do, how you feel, etc. 
5. Speak to your children/pets/plants.
6. Start a club with your friends where you only speak English. 
7. Repeat after me when you watch my videos. 
8. Repeat after the people on TV when you watch TV.
9. Make flashcards with full sentences and practice reading them out loud (speak the words) every day.
10. Read out loud (speak the words) when you are reading. Read the same thing again and again so that you are more confident each time you say it.

text:
Also, it doesn't matter whether or not your speaking partners are native English speakers.

You practice speaking to improve YOUR ABILITY to produce language and become more confident. The important thing is that YOU SPEAK, not who the other person is.

üëç Like | comment üí¨ | save | Share Turn on post notifications üîî

text_entities.text: Here are 10 Easy Ways to Practice Speaking English

1. Sing English songs. 
2. Speak to your mirror every morning about what you are going to do and how you feel. 
3. Speak to your mirror in the evening about what you did and how you felt. 
4. Speak to yourself all day every day about what you are doing, what you need to do, how you feel, etc. 
5. Speak to your children/pets/plants.
6. Start a club with your friends where you only speak English. 
7. Repeat after me when you watch my videos. 
8. Repeat after the people on TV when you watch TV.
9. Make flashcards with full sentences and practice reading them out loud (speak the words) every day.
10. Read out loud (speak the words) when you are reading. Read the same thing again and again so that you are more confident each time you say it.

Also, it doesn't matter whether or not your speaking partners are native English speakers.

You practice speaking to improve YOUR ABILITY to produce language and become more confident. The important thing is that YOU SPEAK, not who the other person is.

text.text:
100 Ways to Say "Great!"üòç

Extraordinary!   ‚ûñ Fabulous! 
Fantastic!          ‚ûñ Fascinating! 
Finest!                ‚ûñ First-rate!

Glorious!            ‚ûñ Grand!
